Dr. S. Mukherjee of The M.S.University of Baroda.

bib_record.title: Systematics of charge distribution studies in low-energy fission of actinides

free_txt: Radiochemistry Division, Bhabha Atomic
Research Centre, Trombay, Mumbai 400 085, India
Research reactors CIRUS and APSARA of
Bhabha Atomic Research Centre, Trombay, Mumbai
The photo peak areas of different gamma rays
were calculated by subtracting the linear Compton
background from their total net peak areas. From the
photo peak areas the cumulative yields of fission
products relative to some internal fission product
monitor were determined using decay equations. The
independent yields were determined from a knowledge
of separation time activities and employing usual
decay-growth equations after correcting for the
precursor contribution. The cumulative yields of
fission products in the thermal neutron-induced
fission of 229-Th, 241-Pu and 245-Cm as well as in
spontaneous fission of 252-Cf were converted to their
fraction yields using the mass chain yields.The
fractional cumulative yields (FCY) of a few fission
products were determined from the activities of the
daughter products using a parent-daughter genetic
equation.
The gamma lines and the nuclear spectroscopic data
of different nuclides were taken from:
* E. Browne, R.B. Firestone, in: V.S. Shirley (Ed.),
Tables of Radioactive Isotopes, 1986.
* J.Blachot,Ch.Fiche, Ann.Phys.(Paris)6,3-218(1981).
The gamma spectrometric analysis of the
separated or unseparated samples were carried out
using a 80 cm**3 HPGe detector coupled to a 4K
channel analyzer in live time mode. The resolution of
the detector system was 2.0 keV at 1332.0 keV and the
dead time was always kept less than 10%.
The uncertainties shown on FCY values are
the propagated errors due to errors on cumulative
yields and mass chain yields where as the
uncertainties quoted in the independent yields are the
standard deviations of  replicate measurements.
Research reactors CIRUS and APSARA of
Bhabha Atomic Research Centre, Trombay, Mumbai
The irradiated solution or
aluminium catcher foils were used for either direct
gamma-ray spectrometry or radiochemical separation of
different fission products such as antimony,
tellurium, iodine, xenon, caesium, barium and rare
earths.
For short-lived fission products, nitrate solutions
of 229-Th (~ 10 mu-g), 241-Pu(~ 2 mu-g) and 245-Cm
(~ 1 mu-g) sealed in polypropylene tubes were taken.
For long-lived fission products,  electrodeposited
targets of 229-Th (~ 100 mu-g), 241-Pu (~ 25 mu-g),
245-Cm (~ 4 mu-g) and 252-Cf (~ 3 mu-g) covered with
0.0025 cm thick aluminium foils were taken.
Approved by Dr.H.Naik, RCD, BARC
